header_summary:
Toby Sharp introduces the Hornet Node and Hornet DSL, a new specification for Bitcoin consensus that employs a declarative and executable approach using modern C++ and a domain-specific language designed for formal verification. This project, which aims to synchronize headers and blocks up to the current endpoint and plans for future script validation, signifies a leap towards improving Bitcoin's consensus mechanism's robustness and reliability. The initiative is documented in detail, inviting collaboration and review from the community, with the potential to make the code publicly available for further engagement ([Hornet Node and the Hornet DSL: A Minimal, Executable Specification for Bitcoin Consensus](hornetnode.org/paper.html)).

ZmnSCPxj elaborates on the RAFT-inspired MultiPTLC competition algorithm, a novel method to enhance payment routing efficiency and reliability within the Lightning Network by enabling parallel path probing and selection from multiple Lightning Service Providers (LSPs). This approach utilizes cryptographic principles for secure transactions and a proof-of-work consensus among LSPs to ensure a democratic and secure transaction process, aiming to improve network resilience and transaction efficiency ([Towards a Global, High-Availability, Consistent, Partition-Tolerant Database for Bitcoin Payments](https://delvingbitcoin.org/t/multichannel-and-multiptlc-towards-a-global-high-availability-consistent-partition-tolerant-database-for-bitcoin-payments/1983/11)).

Guardian's proposed Bitcoin Improvement Proposals (BIPs) introduce a security mechanism, the Guardian Address Signal Protocol, to combat theft by allowing bitcoin wallets to lock in response to duress, without compromising privacy. This protocol enables a secure, on-chain signal for emergency lockdown, addressing the increasing threat of physical attacks on bitcoin users. The proposals, seeking to refine both the overarching approach and technical specifics before formal submission, represent a significant stride towards enhancing bitcoin transaction security ([Proposal: Guardian Address GASPv1](https://delvingbitcoin.org/t/proposal-guardian-address-gaspv1/2006)).

Aqua's inquiry into the operational intricacies of the Lightning Network (LN) highlights the challenges and questions regarding transaction execution without a direct channel between parties, the role of Trampoline Nodes in routing decisions, and the implications of network capacity on large transactions. This discussion underscores the technical and practical considerations essential for leveraging the LN effectively in commercial contexts, particularly for business-to-business transactions ([LN Routing and Caveats](https://delvingbitcoin.org/t/ln-routing-and-caveats/2003)).

recent_posts.title: MultiChannel and MultiPTLC: Towards A Global High-Availability Consistent/Partition-Tolerant Database For Bitcoin Payments

recent_posts.title: [Proposal] Guardian Address + GASPv1
recent_posts.summary:
- Proposed Bitcoin Improvement Proposals introduce a novel security mechanism for theft prevention.
- The Guardian Address Signal Protocol enables emergency lockdowns of bitcoin wallets without on-chain linkages.
- The initiative addresses the need for improved security measures in the face of rising cryptocurrency threats.

recent_posts.title: LN routing and caveats
recent_posts.summary:
- The inquiry explores executing transactions on the Lightning Network without a direct channel.
- It discusses the role of Trampoline Nodes in routing payments and potential operational issues.
- Concerns include routing large B2B transactions, fees, and technical limitations of the LN.

active_posts.title: Stats on compact block reconstructions
active_posts.summary:
- The study examines compact block reconstructions within the Bitcoin network, focusing on transaction awareness.
- Configuration adjustments, like node `dave` increasing connections, impacted block reconstruction efficiency.
- Findings suggest that altering default settings, such as enabling `mempoolfullrbf`, could improve network performance.

active_posts.title: Dust Expiry: Clean the UTXO set from spam
active_posts.summary:
- The UTXO set's rapid growth, now doubled to 11 GB since 2023, is mostly due to spam.
- A proposed soft-fork introduces age-based expiration for dust outputs to combat UTXO set clutter.
- This measure aims to make small, old outputs unspendable, removing spam from the UTXO set.

active_posts.title: Addressing community concerns and objections regarding my recent proposal to relax Bitcoin Core's standardness limits on OP_RETURN outputs
active_posts.summary:
- The proposal debates lifting `OP_RETURN` output limits in Bitcoin Core to improve network efficiency.
- Critics fear it might turn Bitcoin into large-scale data storage, altering its purpose.
- The discourse emphasizes evaluating changes on their technical merits, amidst community divisions.

today_in_history_posts.title: Transaction Input/Output Sorting
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Wallets' method of sorting transactions exposes user privacy due to identifiable patterns.
- Some object to deterministic sorting due to privacy and future compatibility concerns.
- A proposed solution involves deterministic sorting with a semi-secret to seem randomized.

today_in_history_posts.title: RouteBoost: Adding 'r=' fields to BOLT 11 invoices to flag capacity
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Rusty Russell suggested adding an 'r' field to c-lightning invoices for better routing.
- The 'r' field decision is to avoid centralization and aid payment channels.
- ACINQ supported Russell's idea, having thought of it two months earlier.

today_in_history_posts.title: Covenant tools softfork
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- The proposed softfork includes BIP-118, BIP-119, and BIP-345 to enhance Bitcoin security and efficiency.
- BIP-345, focusing on Bitcoin vaults, gains popularity for its quick deployment potential and interest in safer custody.
- The softfork's code, around 7,000 lines, suggests manageable review, with a draft PR for Bitcoin Core pending community feedback.
